coredata.dc:title: Evolution of bond-angle distribution from liquid to glassy states
coredata.dc:creator: Balucani, U.
Vallauri, R.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
The bond-angle distribution of first neighbouring atoms for a metal-like system representative of liquid rubidium is investigated by computer simulation in the liquid, supercooled and glassy states. The results are compared with the predictions derived from an approximate representation of the triplet distribution function.

Italy Received 10 October 1989 The bond-angle distribution of first neighbouring atoms for a metal-like system representative of liquid rubidium is investigated by computer simulation in the liquid, supercooled and glassy states. The results are compared with the predictions derived from an approximate representation of the triplet distribution function. Computer simulation (CS)ofmonatomic systems in supercooled states has been the subject of nu- merous investigations [I], and there has been prog- ress in understanding the liquid glass transition through the recent mode-coupling approaches [2]. Despite the fast thermal quenches used in CS ex- periments to bring the system from its equilibrium liquid phase into a metastable state below the melt- ing temperature, eventually the occurrence of nu- cleation processes leads to the formation of a local crystalline arrangement which rapidly extends over the whole sample. This effect has been thoroughly investigated for different interatomic potential models [3]. Apart from the discontinuities of some thermo- dynamic quantities (such as temperature and pres- sure) when nucleation takes place, the transition from an essentially disordered phase to an ordered one is naturally signalled by the change of spatial correlations, the most obvious being the radial pair distribution function g(R). Another quantity which has been monitored is the distribution of cos 0, where 8 represents the angle between the vectors joining a central particle with two other atoms found within a cut-off distance R~. This quantity, denoted by P(RC, cos 0), intrinsically depends on a three-body correlation function and is naturally more suited to examine the local order, a circumstance exploited in previous CS investigations [3 51. On the other hand, from a theoretical point of view the cosine distri- bution can be used as a probe for testing the validity of expressions capable of describing the three-body distribution function and its state dependence. Work in this direction has been done by Haymet et al. [5,6] in the ordinary liquid and in the crystal, In this Letter we present a systematic CS inves- tigation of the cosine distribution: in particular, its evolution from the liquid phase to supereooled and eventually glassy states is followed by rapidly quenching the temperature of the system. We have chosen a model system representative of a liquid metal, namely rubidium, whose dynamtcal proper- ties in the liquid and supercooled phase have been investigated [4,7], Theoretical predictions obtained by simple approximations of the three-body distri- bution function are compared with the CS results. A discussion of the possible reasons for the observed discrepancies is presented, with the aim of pointing the direction for further improvements to the theory. In our simulation thc particles intcract through the pair pseudo-potential of Price et al. [8], which suc- cessfully accounts for the main structural and dy- namic properties of ordinary liquid rubidium [9]. Starting from an equilibrium configuration in the liquid close to the melting point, namely at T~3l8 K and reduced number density nt=nu3=0.905 (with rr=4.405 A), the system is cooled at constant density to T= 270 K by scaling the velocities of all the N particles in a time interval which corresponds to a quenching rate of l.2x 1012 K/s. After an an- nealing period of about 400 time steps (St= 1 x 10 14 s), the subsequent configurations are used to eval- uate the statistical averages of the explored quan- tities. Most of the simulations are performed with 77 Volume 166, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 9 February 1990 N=250 particles by applying the abovementioned quenching rate: a few of them were done both with N=500 and with a higher quenching rate (~ t.2x t0~ K/s), but no substantial differences were found on the averages. By applying the same quenching program the temperature is lowered to a glassy state at 35 K. In contrast with most dynam- ical correlations, an accurate evaluation of structural properties does not require very long averaging times, thus bypassing any possible tendency of the system to nucleate. For longer runs nucleation events have indeed been observed below 270 K. As a matter of fact, the disagreement is not a con- sequence of the simplifying assumption made for the evaluation of eq. (5); Haymet [5J found similar re- sults for a Lennard-Jones system at the triple point evaluating the double integral of eq. (5) without any simplification. The physical reason for the disagree- ment between CS data and the predictions of eq. (6) at large angles can be understood from the very na- ture of the superposition approximation. By writing the triplet distribution function as the product of three g(r)s, the possible presence of a third, fourth, etc., neighbouring particle is accounted for only in an average way. This effect is overemphasized by the presence of even more atoms between 1 and 2 for configurations where three particles are aligned. Some conclusions can be drawn from the present analysis. It is remarkable that such information can be obtained by looking only at the local order in a first shell of neighbours, contrary to the analysis of the pair distribution function for which the long-range correlations are required. Moreover, the simple criterion of choice of first neighbours (i.e. within a distance where g(R) at- tains its first minimum) makes the analysis much easier, avoiding for example the construction of Vo- ronoi polyhedra. Whereas the theoretical results pre- dicted by the superposition approximation in the co- sine distribution are shown to be fairly good for nearly equilateral triangle configurations, they fail at large angles in the whole range of temperatures ex- plored. In particular, incorrect results are found for collinear configurations (8t 1800) where an un- predicted peak in the cosine distribution is observed both in the glass and in the crystal.
